Meaning: to think about or try to understand something that is confusing or perplexing.

Meaning: to be made up or composed of something; to consist of.

consist of, be composed of, be made up of.

Meaning: Competition for power or influence in an office between different people. Considered usually to be negative.

__2: To get involved in office politics; To stay out of office politics; To avoid office politics; To enjoy office politics; To encourage office politics; To hate office politics; To be sick of office politics; To have to deal with office politics

Meaning: To find faults, flaws, or weaknesses in something, often by criticizing or scrutinizing it.
Examples: Instead of constantly picking holes in others' work, let's focus on constructive feedback and improvement. The reviewer seemed determined to pick holes in the author's argument rather than appreciating the overall message.

Word: Get your foot in the door
Meaning: To establish an initial connection or opportunity that may lead to further success or advancement.
Examples: 1. I managed to get my foot in the door at that company by starting as an intern.. Networking events are a great way to get your foot in the door and meet potential employers.

Meaning: To agree or have the same opinion as someone else.   We don't always see eye to eye, but we respect each other's perspectives.t's important for team members to see eye to eye on the project's objectives.

To pay someone secretly or illegally, usually to avoid taxes or regulations.   The restaurant owner was caught paying employees under the table to avoid payroll taxes.t's illegal to pay workers under the table in many countries.
To discuss work-related topics or engage in conversation about one's profession or industry.
Examples: Whenever we meet up, we always end up talking shop and sharing industry insights.et's grab a coffee and talk shop sometime.

Word: Put something on the back burner
Meaning: To postpone or delay something, usually a task or project, in order to focus on more immediate or pressing matters.   I had to put my plans to start a business on the back burner because of other commitments.he company decided to put the new product development on the back burner until the market conditions improved.
To give up or surrender; to admit defeat.
Examples: After struggling for hours, he finally threw in the towel and accepted that he couldn't solve the problem.It's important to persevere and not throw in the towel when faced with challenges.

Meaning: To put in additional effort or do more than what is expected.
Examples: If you want to succeed, you need to be willing to go the extra mile and exceed expectations.The employee always goes the extra mile to ensure customer satisfaction.

Meaning: To think creatively or unconventionally; to approach a problem or situation in an innovative way.
Examples: In order to find a solution, we need to think outside of the box and consider alternative approaches.The company encourages its employees to think outside of the box and come up with fresh ideas.

Word: Get off on the wrong foot
Meaning: To start a relationship or situation in a negative or unfavorable way.
Examples: We got off on the wrong foot when we had a misunderstanding during our first meeting.It's important to establish a positive first impression and avoid getting off on the wrong foot.

Meaning: To maintain one's position, opinions, or beliefs firmly, especially in the face of opposition or pressure.
Examples: Even when others disagree, it's important to stand your ground if you truly believe in something.The negotiator stood his ground and refused to compromise on the key terms of the agreement.

Word: Run around like a headless chicken
Meaning: To act in a frantic, disorganized, or chaotic manner.
Examples: When the deadline was approaching, everyone was running around like headless chickens trying to get everything done.Instead of panicking and running around like headless chickens, let's approach the situation calmly and systematically.

Meaning: To get to the main point or important information without wasting time on unnecessary details.
Examples: We don't have much time, so let's cut to the chase and discuss the key issues.Instead of beating around the bush, it's better to cut to the chase and address the core problem.

Meaning: Something that initially appears to be negative or unfortunate but turns out to be beneficial or advantageous.
Examples: Losing my job was a blessing in disguise because it pushed me to pursue a career I truly love.Sometimes, setbacks can be a blessing in disguise and lead to unexpected opportunities.

Word: Cost an arm and a leg
Meaning: To be very expensive; to cost a lot of money.
Examples: The new smartphone model looks great, but it costs an arm and a leg.Traveling during peak season can be expensive and may cost you an arm and a leg.

Meaning: To learn the basic skills or procedures of a job or activity.
Examples: As a new employee, it takes time to learn the ropes and become familiar with the company's processes.It's important to have a mentor who can help you learn the ropes in your chosen field.

Meaning: To manipulate financial records or accounts dishonestly, usually for personal gain or to deceive others.
Examples: The company was caught cooking the books to inflate their profits and mislead investors.It's illegal and unethical to cook the books in order to evade taxes or deceive stakeholders.

Meaning: To make an unsolicited phone call or visit to someone, typically for sales or business purposes.
Examples: As a salesperson, you need to be prepared when making cold calls to potential clients.Making cold calls can be challenging, but it can also lead to new business opportunities.

Meaning: To receive approval or permission to proceed with a project, plan, or action.
Examples: After presenting our proposal, we finally got the green light to start the project.The team can't start the development until they get the green light from the management.

Meaning: To persuade or convince someone to do something, often through persistent or forceful means.
Examples: I had to twist his arm to get him to join us for the team outing.The salesperson managed to twist my arm and convince me to buy the product.

Meaning: To operate with a very limited budget or resources.
Examples: As a startup, we had to run on a shoestring budget until we secured more funding.The nonprofit organization manages to run on a shoestring and still make a positive impact.

Meaning: To be overwhelmed or swamped with a large amount of work or responsibilities.
Examples: I can't meet for lunch today; I'm snowed under with deadlines.During the holiday season, retail workers are often snowed under with customer demands.

Meaning: To be in a state of financial loss (in the red) or profit (in the black).
Examples: The company has been struggling and is currently in the red.Thanks to increased sales, the business is finally back in the black.

Word: Be a big fish in a small pond
Meaning: To be important or influential in a small or limited environment or context.
Examples: He enjoys being a big fish in a small pond in his hometown, but he wants to explore bigger opportunities.Some people prefer to be a big fish in a small pond rather than a small fish in a big pond.

Meaning: To be more advanced, innovative, or knowledgeable than others in a particular area.
Examples: The company invests in research and development to stay ahead of the curve in the industry.By constantly learning and adapting, you can stay ahead of the curve in your career.

Meaning: To remain well-informed, organized, and in control of a situation or tasks.
Examples: It's important to stay on top of things to ensure nothing falls through the cracks.With effective time management, you can stay on top of things and avoid feeling overwhelmed.

Meaning: To handle a situation or make decisions as it unfolds, without a predetermined plan.
Examples: We don't have a fixed agenda for the meeting, so let's play it by ear and see how the discussion goes.When traveling, it's sometimes more exciting to play things by ear and be open to unexpected opportunities.

Meaning: To ask someone for advice, information, or opinions on a particular topic.
Examples: I need to pick your brains about the best practices in project management.The new intern is eager to pick the experienced team members' brains and learn from their expertise.

Meaning: To take shortcuts or bypass proper procedures in order to save time, effort, or money.
Examples: Cutting corners in quality control can lead to product defects and customer dissatisfaction.It's important to follow the established guidelines and not cut corners when it comes to safety.

Word: Take the bull by the horns
Meaning: To confront or tackle a difficult or challenging situation directly and with determination.
Examples: Instead of avoiding the problem, it's time to take the bull by the horns and find a solution.The team leader decided to take the bull by the horns and address the team's performance issues.

Meaning: To be dismissed or lose one's job, usually due to poor performance, misconduct, or downsizing.
Examples: He got fired for consistently arriving late to work.Getting fired can be a difficult experience, but it can also be an opportunity for growth and change.

Meaning: To be unproductive, ineffective, or no longer useful in a particular role or organization.
Examples: The company had to let go of employees who were considered dead wood and not contributing to the team.It's important to continuously develop new skills and stay relevant to avoid becoming dead wood in your career.

Meaning: To leave a stressful, competitive, and demanding job or lifestyle in pursuit of a simpler, more fulfilling life.
Examples: After years of working in the corporate world, she decided to quit the rat race and start her own business.Many people dream of quitting the rat race and finding a better work-life balance.

Word: Go back to the drawing board
Meaning: To start over or reconsider a plan, idea, or design because it is not working or needs improvement.
Examples: The initial concept was not well-received, so we had to go back to the drawing board and come up with a new approach.Sometimes, it's necessary to go back to the drawing board and make revisions to achieve better results.

Meaning: To miss an opportunity or fail to take advantage of a favorable situation.
Examples: I missed the boat on investing in that company, and now their stock price has skyrocketed.It's important to stay alert and seize opportunities; otherwise, you may miss the boat.

Meaning: To act prematurely or before the appropriate time; to start or do something too soon.
Examples: Let's not jump the gun and make a decision without considering all the facts.The team announced the product launch date, but they jumped the gun as the development was not yet complete.

Meaning: To be informed or included in a group or situation where important information is shared.
Examples: As a project manager, it's crucial to be in the loop and aware of any updates or changes.The team members meet regularly to ensure everyone is in the loop and aligned with the project goals.

Meaning: To change the rules, requirements, or expectations of a situation or agreement, often to make it more difficult for someone to succeed.
Examples: The company kept moving the goalposts, making it challenging for the employees to meet their targets.It's important to establish clear expectations and not move the goalposts during a project.

Meaning: To become well-known, recognized, or famous, especially in a particular field or location.
Examples: The success of their latest product launch put the company on the map in the tech industry.The city's vibrant art scene has put it on the map as a cultural destination.

Meaning: To do the hard, tedious, or laborious tasks or groundwork that are necessary but not glamorous.

Meaning: To join or support a popular trend, movement, or opinion, often without considering it critically.

Meaning: To maintain control or responsibility for a situation or place while someone is temporarily absent.

Meaning: To yield positive results or benefits over time, often as a result of an investment or effort.

Meaning: To have all the advantages, power, or control in a situation.

Meaning: To quit or retire from a situation or endeavor, often referring to leaving a job or ending a career.

Meaning: To consider, accept, or incorporate something, such as feedback, suggestions, or ideas.

Meaning: To stop working or end an activity for the day.

Examples: I’ll get those invitations off tomorrow.

Meaning: find a way to solve or deal with a difficult problem: giải quyết
Examples: There are many hurdles still to get over before the new restaurant can open.

Meaning: start to feel happy or well again after something bad has happened to you, start to forget someone and feel happy again after a relationship has ended: vượt qua (chuyện buồn)
Examples: It can take weeks to get over an illness like that.

Meaning: finish dealing with some work, a subject, etc: hoàn thành
Examples: I’ve got a lot of work to get through.

Meaning: manage to deal with a difficult situation or stay alive until it is over: thoát được khỏi, sống sót
Examples: How we got through it I’ll never know.

Meaning: use or finish something: dùng, sử dụng
Examples: We get through a litre of milk a day.

Meaning: be connected to a place by telephone: được nối máy
Examples: I tried calling him but I couldn’t get through for some reason.

Meaning: make someone understand what you are trying to say: truyền đạt, giải thích
Examples: The teacher feels he is not getting through to some of the kids in his class.

Meaning: if you give in to something, you can no longer control the feeling of wanting it: thỏa hiệp
Examples: I finally gave in and had a cream cake.

Meaning: stop competing or arguing and accept that you cannot win: chịu thua
Examples: In the end, I gave in and accepted that she was right.

Meaning: become lost or go to the wrong place: bị lạc đường
Examples: We went astray but soon found our way again.

Meaning: produce a particular reaction: (không) được đón nhận (bởi ai)
Examples: The plan to put rents up has not gone down well with tenants.

Meaning: choose something as a subject of study or as your career: theo đuổi ngành/nghề
Examples: I’m going to go in for dentistry.

Meaning: enjoy a particular thing or activity: thích, hưởng ứng
Examples: My dad doesn’t really go in for parties.

Meaning: explode or be fired: phát nổ
Examples: A bomb has gone off in the shopping mall.

Meaning: if food or drink goes off, it is no longer fresh: bị ôi thiu
Examples: Does this milk smell like it’s gone off to you?

Meaning: leave a place, especially for a particular purpose: rời đi
Examples: Pete’s just gone off to get some chewing gum.

Meaning: stop liking someone or something: chán, không còn ưa thích
Examples: I’ve gone off peanuts, for some reason.

Meaning: if two or more things go together, they frequently exist together: đi liền với nhau
Examples: Why do poverty and crime go together so often?

Meaning: if two things go together, they seem good, natural or attractive in combination with each other: phù hợp
Examples: Do this skirt and this top go together?

Meaning: if something or someone grows on you, you start to like them more: khiến ai bắt đầu thích
Examples: I didn’t like that painting at first, but it’s growing on me.

Meaning: lean out of a window so that the top part of your body is outside: thò đầu/ người ra khỏi (cửa sổ)
Examples: Don’t hang out of the window or you’ll fall!

Meaning: spend time in a particular place or with particular people: hẹn hò, đi chơi
Examples: We often just hang out at each other’s houses.

Meaning: prevent someone from going somewhere by getting in front of them: chặn đường
Examples: One police officer chased the robber while the other went to head him off.

Meaning: prevent something from taking place: ngăn chặn
Examples: The UN has sent emergency aid into the area to head off a catastrophe.

Meaning: make something hot; become hot: (làm) nóng lên
Examples: Heat up the baby’s milk, would you?

Meaning: criticise someone who has criticised you: phản pháo
Examples: The Minister hit back at his critics.

Meaning: deliberately hurt someone who has hurt you: trả đòn
Examples: If someone hits you, think before you hit back next time.

Meaning: destroy a building or wall: đổ bỏ, phá hủy
Examples: I see they’ve finally knocked the old factory down.

Meaning: start working hard, especially when you should have done this earlier: bắt tay vào làm, nỗ lực
Examples: It’s time for me to knuckle down and get this finished.

Meaning: speak angrily to or against someone: chỉ trích, đả kích
Examples: They lashed out at the council’s move to stop free parking.

Meaning: try to hit or attack someone suddenly and violently: tấn công
Examples: Occasionally the patients will lash out at the nurses.

Meaning: end someone’s employment, especially temporarily, because there is not enough work for them: sa thải
Examples: They’ve had to cut back production and lay off workers.

Meaning: stop doing or using something, especially for a short period of time: ngừng
Examples: Lay off teasing your brother, Julie!

Meaning: relax and enjoy yourself, doing no work: nghỉ xả hơi
Examples: I’m just planning to laze around this weekend.

Meaning: talk about something that is intended to be a secret: tiết lộ
Examples: He knows more than he lets on.

Meaning: if something lies ahead, it is going to happen to you in the future: trước mắt, ở tương lai
Examples: A bright future lies ahead of him.

Meaning: give something a more interesting appearance, taste or other quality: làm đẹp hơn
Examples: You can liven up a plain shirt with a colourful scarf.

Meaning: make something more interesting or exciting, or become more interesting or exciting: làm thú vị hơn, cải thiện
Examples: What we needed was some music to liven things up.

Meaning: discover something by chance: tình cờ phát hiện. She was scared he might hit upon the truth.
Examples: She was scared he might hit upon the truth.

Meaning: suddenly have an idea: chợt nghĩ ra. They hit upon the idea of celebrating the occasion with a concert.
Examples: They hit upon the idea of celebrating the occasion with a concert.

Meaning: stop someone or something from moving forwards: giữ lại. The police held back the crowd.
Examples: The police held back the crowd.

Meaning: continue to do something: tiếp tục. I don’t think I can afford to keep up my piano lessons.
Examples: I don’t think I can afford to keep up my piano lessons.

Meaning: move at the same speed as someone or something: theo kịp. Dan walks so fast that it’s not easy to keep up with him.
Examples: Dan walks so fast that it’s not easy to keep up with him.

Meaning: put information into a computer or other electronic machine using keys or a keyboard: nhập liệu, đánh máy. All you have to do is key your details in and the computer does the rest.
Examples: All you have to do is key your details in and the computer does the rest.

Meaning: begin (with): bắt đầu. I’d like to kick off with a quick look at last month’s sales figures.
Examples: I’d like to kick off with a quick look at last month’s sales figures.

Meaning: destroy living things so that most or all of them are dead: tàn sát. The pollution killed off all the fish in the lake.
Examples: The pollution killed off all the fish in the lake.

Meaning: stop working: ngừng làm việc. Do you want to knock off early tonight?
Examples: Do you want to knock off early tonight?

Meaning: lock all the doors and windows of a building so that no one can get in: khóa toàn bộ cửa. I must have forgotten to lock up when I left this morning.
Examples: I must have forgotten to lock up when I left this morning.

Meaning: put someone in a prison: tống giam. They should lock him up for a very long time, if you ask me.
Examples: They should lock him up for a very long time, if you ask me.

Meaning: change someone or something so that they become something else: biến đổi thành. It’s as if my parents are trying to make me into the ideal student, so I’m under a lot of pressure.
Examples: It’s as if my parents are trying to make me into the ideal student, so I’m under a lot of pressure.

Meaning: see, hear or understand someone or something with difficulty: nhận ra, xác định. Can you make out a face here in the photograph?
Examples: Can you make out a face here in the photograph?

Meaning: change or improve the appearance of someone or something makeover (n): chỉnh trang, thay đổi diện mạo. They made over three contestants on the show. When they’d finished, they looked completely different.
Examples: They made over three contestants on the show. When they’d finished, they looked completely different.

Meaning: work at different times from usual because you have not worked enough at the normal times: bù vào. Sorry I’m late; I’ll make up the time this evening.
Examples: Sorry I’m late; I’ll make up the time this evening.

Meaning: come together with someone, either unexpectedly or as planned: gặp gỡ. Why don’t we meet up when I’m in Berlin, since it’s not far from you?
Examples: Why don’t we meet up when I’m in Berlin, since it’s not far from you?

Meaning: behave in a silly way: hành xử ngớ ngẩn. Mrs Evans asked the children to stop messing around.
Examples: Mrs Evans asked the children to stop messing around.

Meaning: move so that sb can pass you: nhường đường.
Examples: We stepped aside to let someone in a wheelchair through.

Meaning: visit somewhere before continuing to another place: nghỉ giữa đường.
Examples: We can stop off at the bakery on the way to school.

Meaning: do something that will cause problems in the future: tích lũy, dồn nén.
Examples: If you ignore it, you’re just storing up problems for the future.

Meaning: keep a lot of something so that you can use it later: tích trữ.
Examples: Squirrel store up nuts for the winter.

Meaning: manage to produce a quality or a reaction that helps you deal with a difficult situation: dồn hết can đảm/ sức lực để làm gì.
Examples: He couldn’t summon up the strength to carry on fighting.

Meaning: study something very hard, especially for an examination: học gạo.
Examples: I’ve got to swot up on the French Revolution for tomorrow’s test.

Meaning: look or behave like an older relative: giống.
Examples: Doesn’t she take after her mother?

Meaning: separate an object into pieces: tách rời, tách nhỏ.
Examples: I took my computer apart completely, but I still didn’t find the problem.

Meaning: remove one number or quantity from another number or quantity: trừ, bớt đi.
Examples: If you take three away from five, you’re left with two.

Meaning: separate a large structure into pieces: tháo dỡ.
Examples: After the play, we had to take down all the scenery.

Meaning: write down information or a statement: ghi chép lại.
Examples: The police took down my details.

Meaning: accept something as real or true: chấp nhận.
Examples: He still hasn’t really taken in his father’s death.

Meaning: include something: bao gồm.
Examples: The tour takes in some incredible scenery.

Meaning: become successful or popular very fast: phát lên.
Examples: The new design took off immediately.

Meaning: accept some work or responsibility: nhận nhiệm vụ.
Examples: I can’t take on any more work at the moment.

Meaning: take someone to a place like a cinema or a restaurant and usually pay for them: đưa đi chơi.
Examples: On my birthday, he took me out for dinner.

Meaning: begin to do something that someone else was doing: tiếp quản.
Examples: When my dad retired, I took over the business.

Meaning: gain control of something: nắm quyền kiểm soát.
Examples: Whenever we start organising something, you always want to take over.

Meaning: begin to like someone or something: bắt đầu thích.
Examples: I didn’t take to living here straight away.

Meaning: start doing something as a habit: bắt đầu thói quen.
Examples: I’ve taken to getting up much earlier.

Meaning: talk to someone as if they are not as clever or important as you are: lên giọng kể cả.
Examples: I hate the way Belinda talks down to people.

Meaning: discuss a problem or a plan: thảo luận.
Examples: Let’s talk it over tonight.

Meaning: succeed in persuading someone to agree to something: thuyết phục được.
Examples: I can talk her round.

Meaning: try using something such as a machine or product to find out whether it works correctly or is satisfactory: thử nghiệm.
Examples: I’m taking my new model aeroplane to the park to test it out.

Meaning: consider a problem or decision carefully: cân nhắc kỹ.
Examples: Let’s think over his proposal before we see him again.

Meaning: consider the facts about something in an organised and thorough way: xem xét.
Examples: Have you thought things through?

Meaning: invent or imagine something, especially an excuse: bịa ra.
Examples: She’d have to think up a good reason for being late.

Meaning: force someone to leave a place or group: đuổi, tống cổ.
Examples: Charlie was thrown out of the Scouts.

Meaning: get rid of something that you no longer want, for example by putting it in a dustbin: vứt bỏ.
Examples: We’re throwing these things out.

Meaning: cause something such as dust or water to rise into the air: làm bắn tung lên.
Examples: As the helicopter landed, it threw up a lot of dust.

Meaning: produce something new or unexpected: tạo ra bất ngờ.
Examples: The new rules have thrown up a few problems.

Meaning: help someone to get to the end of a difficult period of time, especially by giving them enough money: giúp vượt qua khó khăn.
Examples: Ed lent me £50 to tide me over until payday.

Meaning: (of an object) have one end move upwards, especially because something heavy has been put at the other end: nghiêng.
Examples: The bench began to tip up and he sat on it.

Meaning: turn a container upside down so that the things inside it come out: lật úp.
Examples: He picked the box up and emptied everything onto the table.

Meaning: make a surface look better with small improvements: trau chuốt, sửa sang.
Examples: Touch up the paintwork before you try to sell the house.

Meaning: test something to see how it works: dùng thử.
Examples: We’re trying out the new system.

Meaning: change or develop into something different: chuyển thành.
Examples: The sofa turns into a bed, so you can stay with us, if you like.

Meaning: change or develop into something different: biến thành.
Examples: They’ve turned the old factory into luxury flats.

Meaning: use all of a supply of something: dùng hết, dùng cạn sạch.
Examples: Did you use the butter up when you were making cakes?

Meaning: leave a meeting, performance, etc. before the end, usually because you are angry or bored: rời đi (vì giận).
Examples: I walked out halfway through the film.

Meaning: suddenly leave a relationship, your family, your job, etc: dứt ngọt bỏ đi, rời khỏi.
Examples: You can’t just walk out like this!

Meaning: do something to prevent someone or something from harming you: phòng ngừa.
Examples: Sheila carried a knife to ward off attacks.

Meaning: prepare for a sport or activity by doing gentle exercises or practising just before it starts warm-up (n): khởi động.
Examples: It’s very important to warm up before you exercise.

Meaning: gradually become thinner and weaker over a period of time, usually because of an illness: dần trở nên gầy gò.
Examples: He hadn’t eaten properly for weeks and was starting to waste away.

Meaning: add water to a drink or liquid in order to make it less strong, dilute: pha loãng.
Examples: If it’s too strong, water it down.

Meaning: make something such as a statement or newspaper article less offensive, powerful or detailed: làm dịu.
Examples: The editor watered my article down.

Meaning: make someone gradually lose their energy or confidence: làm hao mòn.
Examples: This constant criticism at work is really wearing me down.

Meaning: make something gradually disappear or become thinner by using or rubbing it: hư mòn.
Examples: These shoes are uncomfortable because the heel has worn down.

Meaning: use something a lot so that it no longer works, or can no longer be used: làm món cũ, hư hỏng.
Examples: On my walking holiday, I wore out three pairs of boots.

Meaning: cause problems for someone or something or make someone worried: đè nén, gây lo âu.
Examples: The entire industry has been weighed down by economic uncertainty.

Meaning: make someone heavy and unable to move easily: đè nặng lên.
Examples: The waiters were weighed down by huge trays of food.

Meaning: spend time in a relaxed way when you have nothing else to do: giết thời gian.
Examples: We whiled away the Saturday afternoon sitting by the lake.

Meaning: end or finish something gradually: dần tàn, dần chấm dứt.
Examples: The party started to wind down around 2 a.m.

Meaning: gradually reduce work before stopping completely: dần đóng cửa.
Examples: The factory will wind down production before closing next year.

Meaning: relax after a period of excitement or worry: thả giãn, xả hơi.
Examples: It’s hard to wind down after doing such a stressful job all day.

Meaning: damage a vehicle so badly that it is not worth repairing: làm hỏng nặng.
Examples: My uncle wrote his car off in an accident last weekend.

Meaning: decide that someone or something will not succeed and stop giving them your attention and energy: từ bỏ, xóa sổ.
Examples: He felt hopeless; his teachers had written him off.

Meaning: punish someone very severely: trừng phạt ai đó thật nghiêm khắc.
Examples: They’ll really throw the book at him this time.

Meaning: large sum/amount: khoản lớn.
Examples: I’ve managed to put away a tidy sum this year.

Meaning: used when you have said that you have had good luck in order to prevent bad luck from happening to you: phỉ phui, trộm vía.
Examples: I’ll find a new job before too long, touch wood.

Meaning: change your life by starting to be a better person or stopping a bad habit: có một khởi đầu mới.
Examples: Ralph seems to have turned over a new leaf this term.

Meaning: completely controlled by someone else: không thoát khỏi bàn tay của ai.
Examples: I became self-employed because I was sick of being under someone’s thumb.

Meaning: angry and complaining about something: buồn bực, tức giận vì điều gì.
Examples: Everyone in the office is up in arms about having to work next weekend.

Word: variety is the spice of life
Meaning: used for saying that different experiences and situations make life enjoyable or interesting: sự đa dạng là gia vị cuộc sống.
Examples: I do a million different things at work, but I suppose variety is the spice of life.

Meaning: your relative: họ hàng thân thuộc.
Examples: My family is very important to me because, after all, they’re my flesh and blood.

Meaning: happening in a way that is sudden and unexpected: hoàn toàn bất ngờ.
Examples: Then, suddenly, out of the blue, she said she wanted a divorce.

Meaning: extremely good or impressive: tuyệt vời, không thể nào tốt hơn được.
Examples: The food at that restaurant is out of this world!

Meaning: more than what is considered normal or suitable: quá mức, vượt xa.
Examples: Don’t think spending 500 euros on a dress was a bit over the top?

Meaning: the place that is most central or important: vị trí cao quý.
Examples: This stamp’s extremely rare, and takes pride of place in my stamp collection.

Meaning: use your influence in order to get something you want or to help someone: nhờ vả mối quan hệ.
Examples: I don’t think it’s fair to pull strings in order to get a job.

Meaning: provide a sensible way of judging how good, bad, important, etc., something is in comparison to other things: nhận xét, đánh giá đúng vị trí.
Examples: My illness has certainly put everything else in perspective.

Meaning: guess what is happening or what something means based on what you have seen or heard: đoán trước sự việc.
Examples: He didn’t tell us he was retiring, but we could all put two and two together.

Meaning: sit down and relax, especially with your feet raised off the ground: thư giãn.
Examples: Put your feet up and I’ll make dinner.

Meaning: taking a very short/long time to understand or realise something: hiểu nhanh/chậm.
Examples: I’m sure Chad understood what you were suggesting; he’s very quick on the uptake.

Meaning: rest after being very busy, so that you will be ready to start working again: sạc pin, nạp năng lượng.
Examples: Why don’t you take a week off work to recharge your batteries?

Meaning: documents, rules, or processes that cause delays: thủ tục giấy tờ.
Examples: Is there a lot of red tape involved in getting a passport?

Meaning: waste time and effort trying to do something that someone else has already done well: phí công tái tạo.
Examples: Just use the same document you used last time, because there’s no point reinventing the wheel.

Meaning: something that rings a bell sounds familiar to you, although you cannot remember the exact details: nghe hơi quen.
Examples: The name rings a bell but I’m not sure if I’ve ever met her.

Meaning: crazy: điên rồi.
Examples: That noise is driving me round the bend.

Meaning: town or city that is close to and depends on a larger city: thành phố vệ tinh.
Examples: Brentwood is a satellite town just outside London.

Meaning: used for saying someone has been weak in their behaviour, as everyone makes mistakes: ai đó cũng chỉ là người thôi.
Examples: I’m sorry I made a mistake, but I’m only human.

Meaning: agree with someone or have the same opinion as them: đồng tình với ai.
Examples: Imogen and I have never really seen eye to eye.

Meaning: decide that you want something very much: mong muốn điều gì đó xảy ra.
Examples: I had set my heart on getting married on the beach, but the bad weather meant we couldn’t.

Word: sick of one (and) half a dozen of the other
Meaning: used for saying that two things are equally good or bad: kẻ tám lạng, người nửa cân.
Examples: It’s six of one and half a dozen of the other, really.

Meaning: provide a lot of information, especially in an indirect way: biểu lộ sự thật mà không cần nói ra.
Examples: What he said to Mandy speaks volumes about the way he treats his staff.

Meaning: argue or worry about very small details or differences that are not important: cãi nhau vì những điều không quan trọng.
Examples: Whether you call them ‘terrorists’ or ‘freedom fighters’ is just splitting hairs – the point is that they’re killing people!

Meaning: receive a lot of attention because you give the best performance in a show or other event: chiếm sóng, đột phá.
Examples: There was one comedian who really stole the show. She was fantastic!

Meaning: refuse to change what you are saying or doing despite the opposition or criticism of other people: giữ vững niềm tin.
Examples: I admire Kelly for the way she always sticks to her guns.

Meaning: stop moving or reacting suddenly, for example because you are surprised: dừng đột ngột.
Examples: When I heard the gunshot, I stopped dead in my tracks.

Meaning: to follow a path that is quicker and shorter than the usual way: đi đường tắt.
Examples: I walked to school and I used to take a short cut along the canal.

Meaning: spend time thinking about the situation you are in before you decide what to do next: dành nhiều thời gian để nghĩ bước tiếp theo.
Examples: Let’s take a couple of days to take stock of the situation and then we’ll make a decision.

Word: take the law into your own hands
Meaning: punish someone in your own way without involving the police or courts: tự thi hành luật rừng.
Examples: I know you’re angry, but that’s no reason to take the law into your own hands.

Meaning: follow a longer path than usual because it is more attractive: đi đường vòng để ngắm cảnh.
Examples: We’re not lost – we’re just taking the scenic route.

Meaning: tell someone in authority bad things that someone else has done: mách lẻo, đặt điều.
Examples: Toby, stop telling tales about your classmates.

Meaning: an advantage that makes someone or something more successful than other people or things: lợi thế hơn so với ai.
Examples: Our product’s got the edge over the competition because it’s so lightweight.

Meaning: used for saying people have limited control over what life brings them: hên xui.
Examples: I never wanted to become a butcher, but I guess that’s the luck of the draw.

Meaning: recently: một hôm, gần đây.
Examples: There was an interesting item on the news the other day.

Meaning: people who control a situation: người nắm quyền.
Examples: I don’t know if the powers that be will agree to that.

Meaning: the skills and equipment you need in order to do your job: các công cụ, đồ nghề.
Examples: A good bedside manner is one of the tools of the trade for a doctor.

Meaning: used for saying that you should accept other people’s beliefs and way of life: sống để mà dễ sống.
Examples: I don’t agree with what he’s doing, but live and let live, I say.

Meaning: including everything: tất thảy.
Examples: They’ve sold all their possessions, lock, stock and barrel.

Meaning: become confused about where you are: hoang mang, mất phương hướng.
Examples: I lost my bearings for a moment, but then realised where I was.

Meaning: go towards someone or something in the quickest and most direct way: tiến thẳng về phía ai/cái gì.
Examples: As soon as we arrived at the hotel, Molly made a beeline for the manager to complain.

Meaning: feel relaxed and behave in the same way as in your home: cư xử như ở nhà.
Examples: Charles will be down in a moment, so please make yourselves at home.

Word: never/don’t look a gift horse in the mouth
Meaning: if you are given something good, you should not complain about it: đừng xét nét quà tặng.
Examples: The flat wasn’t in very good condition, but we were staying there rent-free, and you should never look a gift horse in the mouth, should you?

Meaning: for emphasising that there is no reason or explanation: chẳng ra sao, vô lý.
Examples: There seems to be no rhyme or reason for the decision.

Word: not have a leg to stand on
Meaning: not have any way of proving that you are right about something: không thể nào chứng minh mình đúng.
Examples: George tried to argue that the world was flat, but of course he didn’t have a leg to stand on.

Word: not see the wood for the trees
Meaning: used for saying that someone cannot understand what is important in a situation: chỉ thấy cây mà không thấy rừng.
Examples: Many people can’t see the wood for the trees when talking about joining the eurozone; they just think about what’s on the notes and coins and don’t think about the economic benefits.

Meaning: away from populated areas or areas popular with tourists: nơi ít người biết đến.
Examples: We like to get off the beaten track when we go on holiday.

Meaning: have a good relationship with someone: có mối quan hệ tốt với.
Examples: When I left the job, I was still on good terms with everyone in the office.

Word: on the spur of the moment
Meaning: do something suddenly without planning: nổi hứng làm gì.
Examples: We booked the holiday on the spur of the moment. We hadn’t been planning to take a break at all this summer.

Meaning: with no place to live: vô gia cư.
Examples: Life is hard on the street.

Meaning: spending the evening enjoying yourself in bars, clubs, theatres: đi chơi tận hưởng.
Examples: Did you go out on the town on your birthday?

Meaning: very rarely: hiếm khi.
Examples: To be honest, I only go to museums once in a blue moon. I just don’t have time usually.

Meaning: extremely happy: cực kỳ vui sướng.
Examples: She was over the moon about her results.

Meaning: an essential part of something: phần không thể thiếu.
Examples: Working irregular hours is all part and parcel of being a journalist.

Meaning: pass responsibility for a problem to someone else: đùn đẩy trách nhiệm.
Examples: The minister tried to pass the buck by blaming his civil servants for the mistake.

Meaning: deal with a situation as it develops: tùy cơ ứng biến.
Examples: We can’t make a decision yet. Let’s just play it by ear.

Meaning: get satisfaction from something that you do well: tự hào về điều gì.
Examples: Emily prides herself on her skills as a negotiator.

Meaning: trick someone: lừa đảo.
Examples: You paid £200 for that? He really pulled a fast one on you!

Word: put your cards on the table
Meaning: tell people exactly what you are thinking or intending to do: thẳng thắn nói rõ.
Examples: I’m going to lay my cards on the table and offer you an extra £1,000. But that’s my final offer!

Meaning: sit down and relax: nghỉ ngơi, thư giãn.
Examples: Put your feet up for half an hour – you look absolutely exhausted.

Word: put your money where your mouth is
Meaning: show by action that you support or believe something: thể hiện niềm tin bằng hành động.
Examples: If you’re really serious about quitting your job, it’s time to put your money where your mouth is and hand in your resignation.

Word: put yourself in someone else’s shoes
Meaning: imagine what it would be like to be in someone else’s situation: đặt mình vào vị trí người khác.
Examples: Try to put yourself in her shoes – how would you feel if your boss spoke to you like that?

Meaning: find a hidden meaning in something that is not said openly: đọc giữa các dòng.
Examples: He didn’t seem too upset, but I suppose you have to read between the lines.

Meaning: something that takes people’s attention away from what is important: đánh lạc hướng.
Examples: His remarks about the Prime Minister were just a red herring to distract attention from the main issue.

Meaning: a very important or exciting day: ngày đáng nhớ.
Examples: It was a red-letter day when we moved into our new house.

Meaning: waste time and effort doing something that has already been done well: phí công tái tạo.
Examples: Just use the same document you used last time, because there’s no point reinventing the wheel.

Meaning: sound familiar to you: nghe quen quen.
Examples: The name rings a bell, but I’m not sure if I’ve ever met her.

Meaning: because of a sudden feeling that you must do or say something: làm chuyện gì một cách ngẫu hứng.
Examples: Wendy decided on a whim to redecorate the whole house.

Meaning: having a long period of difficulty finding work or earning money: gặp khó khăn.
Examples: The man was work and earning money, obviously down on his luck, so I gave him a little money.

Meaning: say that you definitely will not allow or accept something: không đồng ý hoàn toàn.
Examples: I don’t mind you asking if you can borrow some money, but I draw the line at you taking it out of my purse without asking first.

Meaning: suddenly become extremely angry without a good reason: nổi khùng.
Examples: Whatever she says, don’t fly off the handle. Stay calm!

Meaning: full of enthusiasm
Examples: Last spring, a zealous political activist lived in a tree to ensure it wouldn't be cut down.

Meaning: go straight forward, without turning: cứ đi thẳng đường rẽ.
Examples: Once you go past the traffic lights, just follow your nose.

Meaning: highest point
Examples: The zenith of Bert's career was when he sang on stage at the Grand Old Opry.

Meaning: leave a job so that sb can take over (về hưu)
Examples: The chairman stepped aside to allow a younger person to take over

Meaning: for now: trong lúc này.
Examples: I’m staying in rented accommodation for the time being, but hope to buy a place early next year.

Meaning: improve the appearance of st, e.g. by cleaning up or painting (cải thiiện bề ngoài, cải tạo)
Examples: This room needs smartening up.

Meaning: sometimes, but not often: đôi khi.
Examples: We see Brian from time to time, but not regularly.

Meaning: take control or advantage over a person or situation: đoạt quyền kiểm soát hoặc lợi ích hơn.
Examples: It looked like Ivor was going to win the game, but I soon got the upper hand.

Word: get on like a house on fire
Meaning: become good friends very quickly and have a lot to talk to each other about: có quan hệ hòa thuận.
Examples: George and Isabelle seem to be getting on like a house on fire, don’t they?

Meaning: talk to someone about something that has been worrying you: giãi bày tâm sự.
Examples: It feels such a relief to have got this off my chest.

Word: get the wrong end of the stick
Meaning: understand something completely wrongly: hiểu lầm.
Examples: Don said he was going to France and I got the wrong end of the stick and thought he was moving there forever.

Meaning: understand the basic meaning: nắm được ý chính.
Examples: Doreen and I have been having some problems recently, if you catch my drift.

Word: give sb a taste/dose of their own medicine
Meaning: treat someone in the same way that they treat other people: trả đũa.
Examples: He got me into trouble, so I’m going to give him a taste of his own medicine!

Meaning: promise to do something: hứa hẹn với ai.
Examples: I give you my word I won’t tell anyone.

Meaning: decide not to do something that you usually do: không làm việc gì.
Examples: I think I’ll give the office party a miss this year.

Meaning: share the cost of something equally: mỗi người trả phần mình.
Examples: Let’s go halves on the meal, shall we?

Meaning: if success goes to your head, it makes you think that you are better or more important than you really are: kiêu căng, ngạo mạn.
Examples: I hope getting that scholarship doesn’t go to Carol’s head.

Meaning: accept a difficult situation without complaining or showing how you feel: ngậm bồ hòn làm ngọt.
Examples: Alan just has to grin and bear it because he needs a bad review.

Meaning: change your opinion about something or decide not to do something you were planning to do: đổi ý.
Examples: Y. Williams had a change of heart and decided not to go to university after all.

Meaning: be good at growing plants: có tài trồng cây.
Examples: My wife’s always had green fingers, whereas I don’t know anything about growing plants.

Meaning: have more time available than you need: dư thời gian.
Examples: Julie has a lot more time on her hands now that her children have all left home.

Meaning: be able to think quickly and make sensible decisions: thông thái.
Examples: You’ve got to have your wits about you when dealing with pushy salespeople.

Meaning: the way in which information spreads quickly: nghe từ nguồn tin không chính thức.
Examples: I heard through the grapevine you might be getting married soon.

Word: be born with a silver spoon in your mouth
Meaning: have advantages because you come from a rich family: sinh ra đã ngậm thìa vàng, sinh ra ở vạch đích.
Examples: I’ve always had to work hard because I wasn’t born with a silver spoon in my mouth.

Meaning: understand the way another thinks because you often have the same ideas and opinions: cùng tần số, cùng quan điểm.
Examples: It was a difficult meeting because David and I didn’t seem to be on the same wavelength.

Meaning: something that makes a place look less attractive, for example, an ugly building: phá hủy phong cảnh.
Examples: Many people in the town think that the old factory is a blot on the landscape.

Meaning: if a person or business breaks even, they neither make a profit nor lose money: hòa vốn.
Examples: We didn’t make a profit last year, but we did break even.

Meaning: change a situation by doing something that is very different from what most people usually do or have done in the past: phá cách.
Examples: I thought her last movie really broke the mould.

Word: bury your head in the sand
Meaning: ignore a problem or an unpleasant situation and hope that it will disappear: làm đà điểu, trốn tránh sự thật.
Examples: We shouldn’t just bury our heads in the sand and hope that this problem goes away.

Meaning: change your opinion or attitude: đổi ý.
Examples: Tom often criticised Nadia until he met her, but now he’s changed his tune.

Meaning: completely honest or legal: trong sạch.
Examples: I’m not worried about the tax inspection. This company’s accounts are clean as a whistle.

Meaning: extremely clean: sạch bong.
Examples: My mum’s coming to visit tomorrow so I want the house to be as clean as a whistle when she gets here.

Meaning: tell the truth about something that you have kept secret: nói sự thật.
Examples: You’d better come clean and tell Mum it was you who broke the flowerpot.

Meaning: used for saying that something always happens or someone always does something despite bad weather or difficult conditions: dù thế nào đi chăng nữa.
Examples: I’m determined to finish building the house by the end of the month, come rain or shine.

Meaning: area surrounding a large city where many people who work in that city live: khu vực vành đai thành phố.
Examples: Towns in the commuter belt often seem to lack character.

Meaning: unpleasant part of a city where there are a lot of ugly buildings close together: rừng bê tông, khu vực nhà cửa san sát.
Examples: Where we used to live was a bit of a concrete jungle.

Meaning: someone who spends a lot of time sitting at home watching television: người hay xem tivi và lười vận động.
Examples: I’ve become a bit of a couch potato since I stopped playing football.

Meaning: waste time feeling upset about something bad that has happened and cannot be changed: tiếc rẻ con gà quạ tha.
Examples: I know your CD player’s broken, but there’s no point crying over spilt milk, is there?

Meaning: build a structure or put it in a particular place: xây dựng.
Examples: They set up the tent near the lake.

Meaning: prevent someone from being heard by shouting: la ó, hét lớn.
Examples: The protesters shouted down the politician during his speech.

Meaning: become weaker or smaller in amount: giảm sút.
Examples: The flowers shriveled up in the heat.

Meaning: choose one person from a group for special attention: chọn ra.
Examples: She was singled out for her outstanding performance.

Meaning: think carefully and form an opinion about a person or situation: đánh giá.
Examples: He sized up the situation before making a decision.

Meaning: leave secretly: lẻn đi.
Examples: He slipped away before the meeting ended.

Meaning: make a careless mistake: sơ suất.
Examples: I slipped up and sent the wrong email.

Meaning: to make yourself look tidy and clean: làm đẹp lên.
Examples: You should smarten up before your job interview.

Meaning: be so busy you cannot deal with it: ngập trong việc.
Examples: I'm completely snowed under with work right now.

Meaning: find out someone’s opinions or feelings: dò hỏi ý kiến.
Examples: I need to sound out their opinions before we proceed.

Meaning: state your opinion firmly: lên tiếng, nói rõ.
Examples: She spoke out against the unfair treatment.

Meaning: if people in a group spread out, they move away from one another: tản ra.
Examples: The campers spread out their sleeping bags in the field.

Meaning: be produced suddenly and quickly: đột ngột xuất hiện.
Examples: New cafes have sprung up all over the city.

Meaning: be easy to see or notice because of being different: nổi bật.
Examples: Her bright clothes made her stand out in the crowd.

Meaning: not allow yourself to be treated badly: đứng lên chống lại.
Examples: He stood up to his boss and refused to work overtime.

Meaning: leave a job so that sb else can take over: từ chức.
Examples: The chairman stepped aside to let the younger manager take over.

Meaning: leave a position of power: từ bỏ chức vụ.
Examples: She decided to step down after ten years as CEO.

Meaning: increase intensity or effort: tăng cường.
Examples: We need to step up our efforts to finish this project.

Meaning: stick out or extend outward: nhô ra.
Examples: The tree branch stuck out over the road.

Meaning: leave angrily or suddenly: bỏ đi.
Examples: He stormed out of the meeting in frustration.

Meaning: summarize or present key points: tóm tắt.
Examples: He summed up the discussion in a few sentences.

Meaning: stop paying attention: ngừng tập trung.
Examples: Please switch off the lights when you leave.

Meaning: accompany someone uninvited: theo sau.
Examples: I decided to tag along with them to the park.

Meaning: gradually decrease or fade: giảm dần.
Examples: Her voice tailed off as she forgot the lyrics.

Meaning: speak in a condescending manner: nói giọng hạ thấp.
Examples: He talked down to us as if we were children.

Meaning: persuade someone to do something: thuyết phục ai làm gì.
Examples: They talked me into joining their team.

Meaning: dissuade someone from doing something: thuyết phục ai không làm gì.
Examples: I talked her out of making a rash decision.

Meaning: demolish or destroy: phá hủy.
Examples: The building was torn down to make way for new apartments.

Meaning: consider something carefully: cân nhắc kỹ.
Examples: I'll think over your proposal and give you an answer tomorrow.

Meaning: discard or get rid of something: vứt bỏ.
Examples: Don't throw away that old vase; it's an antique.

Meaning: eject or remove forcibly: đuổi ra.
Examples: They threw out the old furniture to make space.

Meaning: reprimand or scold: trách mắng.
Examples: She ticked off the items on the checklist.

Meaning: inform secretly or warn: báo tin.
Examples: The police were tipped off about the robbery.

Meaning: finish or complete something: hoàn thành.
Examples: We topped off the meal with a delicious dessert.

Meaning: adjust or tune a device: điều chỉnh.
Examples: You can tune in to the news at 8 PM.

Meaning: refuse entry: từ chối vào.
Examples: They turned away visitors who didn't have tickets.

Meaning: result in or prove to be: hóa ra là.
Examples: The event turned out to be a huge success.

Meaning: consume completely: sử dụng hết.
Examples: We've used up all the milk.

Meaning: leave suddenly or unexpectedly: rời đi bất ngờ.
Examples: The workers walked out in protest of the new policies.

Meaning: become very tired: mệt mỏi rã rời.
Examples: These shoes have completely worn out after years of use.

Meaning: spend time doing things in a relaxed way: thư giãn.
Examples: There's nothing I like better than messing about in the garden.

Meaning: make a mistake or do something badly: gây lỗi, làm sai.
Examples: She says she completely messed up the interview.

Meaning: put things together without any order: trộn lẫn.
Examples: If you put different colors into different glasses and mixed them up, could you tell which was which?

Meaning: get much larger: tăng vọt.
Examples: The costs are beginning to mount up.

Meaning: start living in a different house or flat (with): chuyển tới (nơi ở mới).
Examples: When he got divorced, John moved in with me.

Meaning: leave one place and travel to another: rời đi.
Examples: My job means that I tend to stay in one city for a year or two and then move on.

Meaning: permanently leave the house or flat where you live: rời khỏi (nơi ở cũ).
Examples: I hear you've finally moved out of your parents' place.

Meaning: change your position in order to make space for someone or something: dịch sang.
Examples: The woman moved over so that I could sit on the bench.

Meaning: think carefully about something over a period of time: nghiền ngẫm.
Examples: They'll need time to mull over the proposals.

Meaning: make it easier to travel or do business in a country: mở cửa.
Examples: You'd be amazed at how much China has opened up since you were there.

Meaning: decide not to take part in something or stop taking part in it: chọn không tham gia.
Examples: Quite a few of the students have opted out of the school trip.

Meaning: hide a problem or disagreement rather than finding a satisfactory solution to it: che giấu.
Examples: Fundamental problems were papered over, not resolved.

Meaning: die (used to avoid saying 'die'): qua đời.
Examples: He passed away in his sleep at the age of 84.

Meaning: become friends with someone again after a disagreement: hàn gắn.
Examples: The meeting was intended to patch up relations between the two sides.

Meaning: give someone the same amount of money you borrowed from them: hoàn trả.
Examples: I'll be able to pay you back next week.

Meaning: spend or pay money, especially a lot of money: trả.
Examples: We've paid out thousands of pounds in health insurance over the years.

Meaning: gradually stop using something: loại bỏ dần.
Examples: They're phasing out the old-style driving licence.

Meaning: keep treating someone badly or unfairly: trêu chọc.
Examples: Why don't you pick on someone your own size?

Meaning: go and meet someone or something: đón.
Examples: Detectives are still piecing together the circumstances surrounding the incident.

Meaning: learn the truth about something by considering all separate bits of information: lắp ghép thông tin.
Examples: The printer's playing up again.

Meaning: if something piles up or someone piles it up, the amount of it increases a lot: chất đống.
Examples: The US has been propping up the government in that country for years.

Meaning: cause difficulties or pain for someone: gây khó chịu.
Examples: Could you just pull over for a second?

Meaning: continue doing something in a determined way: quyết tâm tiến hành.
Examples: Don't worry, your dad's going to pull through.

Word: Your Guess is as Good as Mine
Meaning: To have no idea about anything
Examples: Will this flight reach on time?” “Your guess is as good as mine.”
Translation: Chắc cô cũng thắc mắc giống tôi đấy.

Meaning: The person you’re talking about shows up at the exact time
Examples: I hope he doesn’t show up to the office today – oh, speak of the devil, here he comes.
Translation: - Oh! Tiếng nói của quỷ sứ, hi.

Meaning: No manners
Examples: The class showed not a spark of decency by refusing to stand up when their principal entered the classroom.

Word: In the heat of the Moment
Meaning: Overwhelmed by what is happening at the moment
Examples: I’m afraid I was very arrogant; I was caught up in the heat of the moment.

Meaning: To hear rumours
Examples: I heard on the grapevine that my brother-in-law got the promotion, but I really don’t know much about it.”

Meaning: A person who advocates an unpopular cause for the sake of an argument.
Examples: I don’t really believe all that – I was just playing devil’s advocate.

Meaning: Under his control
Examples: I feel like I’m always under his thumb.
Translation: Dưới ngón tay cái của anh ấy

Meaning: In short periods, not regularly
Examples: The project progressed in fits and starts, with periods of intense productivity followed by long periods of inactivity.

Meaning: Strange
In a very difficult situation
Examples: Alex realized they were in a tight corner when the client demanded a lower price.
Translation: Ở trong một góc chật hẹp

Meaning: The anxiety in which you hope that nothing will upset your plans
Examples: I have a job interview tomorrow, so I’m keeping my fingers crossed that it goes well and I get the position.
Translation: cầu mong điều tốt đẹp xảy ra" hoặc "giữ niềm hy vọng".

Meaning: Talent for speaking
Examples: With his natural charisma and the gift of the gab, he could effortlessly captivate any audience with his storytelling.

Word: Cost an Arm and a Leg
Meaning: Be very expensive
Examples: The vintage car restoration ended up costing me an arm and a leg, but it was worth it to see it gleaming again.

Meaning: Suspect something foul
Examples: After seeing how eager he was to sell his car for such a low price, I began to smell a rat and suspected that there might be something wrong.

Meaning: By fair or foul means
Examples: She was willing to do whatever it took—by hook or by crook—to meet the deadline.

Meaning: Spread quickly
Examples: The news of the new product launch spread like wildfire through social media, garnering attention and excitement from users around the world.
Translation: Lây lan như một đám cháy rừng

Meaning: Disturb the work
Examples: The sudden power outage threw the entire production process out of gear, causing delays and disruptions.
Translation: không khớp bánh răng; không gài số

Meaning: Die while in service
Examples: Even in his old age, he continued to teach and inspire his students until he eventually died in harness, doing what he loved most.

Meaning: To be very busy
Examples: I can’t go out tonight, I’m absolutely snowed under with work and deadlines

Meaning: To be dismissed from your job
Examples: After consistently showing up late for work, he eventually got the sack from his job

Word: Don’t give up a day’s job
Meaning: You are not very good at something or you could not do it professionally
Examples: I love painting, but I shouldn’t give up a day’s job just yet.
Translation: Đừng từ bỏ công việc của một ngày

Meaning: To make certain that the amount of money spent is not more than the amount of money received
Examples: The company was accused of balancing the books to inflate its profits and deceive investors.

Meaning: A general financial figure
Examples: The project manager gave us a ballpark figure for the budget, estimating it to be around $50,000, but the actual costs could vary.

Meaning: Newspapers which publish sensational and unscrupulous stories and exaggerate the news to attract readers.
Examples: Don’t believe everything you read in the yellow press. They often exaggerate stories for sensationalism

Meaning: An event which relates a sensation for a time but is soon forgotten
Examples: The new gadget was a nine-day wonder, capturing everyone’s attention for a short time before they moved on to the next big thing.
Translation: Điều kỳ diệu của chín ngày

Word: One swallow does not make a summer
Meaning: It is unreliable to base one’s conclusions on only a single test or incident
Examples: Just because John aced one test doesn’t mean he’ll excel in the whole course. Remember, one swallow does not make a summer.
Translation: Một con én không làm nên mùa xuân.

Meaning: To exert all efforts
Examples: Sarah was determined to move heaven and earth to ensure her project’s success.
Translation: khuấy đảo trời đất, dùng đủ mọi biện pháp, xoay xở đủ trò

Word: A miss is as good as a mile
Meaning: Comes nowhere near the target
Examples: She didn’t win the race, but her coach reminded her that in the end, a miss is as good as a mile.
Translation: Sai một ly đi một dặm

Meaning: The whole of everything
Examples: After years of negotiations, they finally decided to buy the company lock, stock, and barrel.

Word: Make hay while the sun shines
Meaning: Take advantage of all opportunities
Examples: You should go and make hay while the sun shines, as this could be your chance to secure a great job.
Translation: dạy trẻ từ thủa con thơ, dạy vợ lúc lúc bơ vơ mới về

Word: All that glitters are not gold
Meaning: Things that appear attractive or valuable on the surface may not always be as good as they seem.
Examples: She realized that all that glitters is not gold and that a high-paying job isn’t always worth sacrificing her happiness and health.
Translation: Chớ thấy sáng mà tưởng là vàng

Word: To jump from a frying pan into fire
Meaning: To come out of one trouble and get into a worse
Examples: He ended up jumping from the frying pan into the fire when he started his new job at a company.
Translation: Nhảy từ chảo rán vào lửa

Meaning: Cheating
Examples: The police suspected foul play in the sudden disappearance of the valuable painting from the museum.

Meaning: Anyone in an awkward
Examples: Sarah felt like a fish out of water at the fancy gala, surrounded by wealthy socialites and unfamiliar customs.

Word: A burnt child dreads the fire
Meaning: One who has had a previous unpleasant experience is always scared of situations where such experiences are likely to be repeated
Examples: After getting food poisoning from a street vendor, she never ate street food again; a burnt child dreads the fire.

Word: To set the Thames on fire
Meaning: To do something sensational or remarkable
Examples: It’s clear that he thinks he’s going to set the Thames on fire with his revolutionary ideas.

Meaning: Useless possession which is extremely expensive to keep
Examples: He was getting a great deal when he bought that antique vase, but it turned out to be a real white elephant.
Translation: bỏ thì thương, vương thì tội

Word: To throw dust in one’s eyes
Meaning: To try to deceive someone or mislead someone
Examples: The company’s CEO tried to throw dust in everyone’s eyes by giving a carefully crafted speech.

Meaning: Sooner or later, everyone has his share of good fortune
Examples: When he unexpectedly won the Employee of the Month award, he proved that every dog has his day.
Translation: Sông có lúc, người có lúc

Word: Give a dog a bad name and hang him
Meaning: Once a person loses his reputation
Examples: They’re just trying to give a dog a bad name and hang him, without any concrete evidence to support their claims.
Translation: Đặt tên xấu cho chó và treo cổ nó

Meaning: Playing Cards
Examples: To the curious explorers, the place felt like the Devil’s playthings, where forgotten memories and eerie whispers seemed to linger in the air

Meaning: Be off
Examples: After enduring his rude comments for far too long, Jane finally had enough and told him to go to the devil.
Translation: quỷ tha ma bắt mày đi!

Word: To step into dead man’s shoes
Meaning: To come into an inheritance
Examples: Jane found herself having to step into the dead man’s shoes and lead the company through these challenging times.
Translation: Để bước vào đôi giày của người chết

Meaning: Refers to a period of peace, tranquility, and happiness
Examples: She would often talk about the halcyon days she spent at her grandparent's farm.

Meaning: A period of misfortune
Examples: Many families struggled to make ends meet and faced evil days as they navigated through job losses and financial instability.

Meaning: Ready made
Examples: Sarah was cut and dried, as she had consistently outperformed her colleagues and had the most experience in the department.

Word: Too many cooks spoil the broth
Meaning: Where there are more workers than necessary leading to disappointment
Examples: Everyone had their own ideas for the project, but too many cooks spoil the broth, and the final result ended up being confusing and ineffective.

Meaning: To learn by heart
Examples: I spent hours studying the poem so that I could learn it by heart and recite it perfectly during the poetry recitation competition.

Word: To throw cold water upon anything
Meaning: To discourage efforts
Examples: The manager threw cold water upon their ambitious ideas by pointing out the potential budget constraints.
Translation: Ném nước lạnh vào bất cứ thứ gì

Meaning: A foolishly incredible story
Examples: His explanation for why he was late to the meeting was a foolishly incredible story about being abducted by aliens.

Meaning: To be mean
Examples: As known for being close-fisted when it came to lending money to his friends.

Meaning: To attempt something impossible
Examples: Trying to convince her strict parents to let her go on a solo backpacking trip was like trying to square the circle.

Meaning: Refers to the fact that its time for action now
Examples: She did her best and the ball is now in your court.
Translation: Bóng đang ở sân của bạn

Meaning: To make a careful selection
Examples: She can’t just pick and choose which tasks she wants to do.

Meaning: She is older than she says

Meaning: GOGGLES
Examples: I can’t remember the word for them, but they help you to see under water.

Meaning: SALMON
Examples: I’ve forgotten the name for it, but it’s a type of fish with red meat and is normally quite expensive.

Meaning: A FLIGHT ATTENDANT
Examples: I don’t recall the word for this profession, but it’s a person who helps passengers on a plane.

Meaning: DYE
Examples: I’ve forgotten the verb, but it’s when you change the colour of something, for example your hair or your car.

Meaning: EMBEZZLEMENT
Examples: The name of this crime is on the tip of my tongue but I can’t quite recall it. It’s a form of crime where someone dishonestly takes money that is entrusted to him or her.

Meaning: ASTHMA
Examples: The name of this condition has completely slipped my mind. It’s when you have problems breathing.

Meaning: AN OWL
Examples: I’ve never come across the name of this animal in English. It’s a nocturnal bird with large eyes, a flat face and a flexible neck.”

Meaning: If the examiner uses a word or phrase that you didn’t understand or that you have forgotten, for example the verb exaggerate, you can say something
Examples: Sorry, but could you explain what you mean by exaggerate? I haven’t heard that word before. Could you explain what you mean? Sorry, I’m not sure what that word means. Could you explain it another way? Sorry, I don’t know what exaggerate means. Could you explain it another way? Sorry, I’ve forgotten what exaggerate means. Could you explain it another way?

Meaning: If you simply didn’t hear what the examiner said or asked, you can say something
Examples: Excuse me, I didn't quite catch that. Could you say it again? Sorry, I didn’t hear what you said. Could you repeat it? I'm sorry, but would you mind repeating that? (MORE POLITE)

Meaning: In Part 3 of the IELTS speaking test, you will be asked a question related to the topic of Part 2, and you might need more time to think than you did in Part 1. Simple conversation fillers might not be enough to buy yourself the time that you need before answering the question. Here are some more effective techniques.
Examples: Repeat the question - When the examiner asks the question, try to repeat it in your own

Meaning: If you ask yourself a direct question, you need to use standard question word
Examples: How popular is TV in my country? – How do I like to spend my free time?

Meaning: Another way to give yourself extra time to think about your response is simply to ask for time. This is a technique that everybody uses in normal conversation.
Examples: Interesting question. Can I think about it for a minute? ; Okay, that’s a difficult question. Can you give me a moment to think about it?; Hmm...good question. Can I have a little time to think about it?; If you are aiming for a very high band, you can consider using the following expressions; That’s an interesting question. Can I dwell on it for a moment?; Okay, that’s a tricky question. I just need a moment to think it over; Okay, that’s a tricky question. I just need a moment to ponder over it.

Meaning: If you still need a few extra seconds after using the above expressions, you can begin your response with a suitable conversation filler.
Examples: Well, I guess I would say that television is extremely popular’ Hmm....I suppose that train travel is the most common form of transport; Well, umm, basically I think that sport can help us to live a much healthier lifestyle.

Meaning: In order to buy yourself the maximum time that you need, consider all three approaches
Examples: What different types of food do people eat in your country?-- Hmm....so you would like to know the different types of food that people eat in my country. Hmm...interesting question. Can I think about it for a moment? Well, I guess traditional Polish cuisine is still very popular.

Meaning: In Part 2 and 3 of the IELTS speaking test, you will need to speak at length about a particular issue. In order to get a high band, it is important to develop your ideas using appropriate connecting words and phrases. Imagine the examiner asks if you would prefer to live in a big or small city. Study how the connecting words/phrases in bold are used in the answer below.
Examples: Well, I think on the whole I’d prefer to live in a big city. Firstly, there are more job opportunities. On top of that, the standard of living is higher and the infrastructure is more developed. Also, there are more places to go shopping. In short, there are lots of advantages. On the other hand, I think there are several important drawbacks. First of all, big cities tend to be more polluted because of all the cars. Secondly, there is more noise. Regarding transport, big cities can be very stressful. For example, my home city Moscow has a very crowded metro system. In fact, it’s one of the most stressful metro systems in the world. However, despite those disadvantages, I’d still prefer to live in a big city.

Meaning: Talking in general
Examples: I think on the whole I’d prefer to live in a big city.

Meaning: Introducing a topic
Examples: Regarding transport, big cities can be very stressful.

Meaning: Listing different points Firstly, First of all, Secondly,
Examples: On top of that, the standard of living is higher and the infrastructure is more developed.

Word: On the other hand, However, Despite (those disadvantages),
Meaning: Introducing a contrast
Examples: However, despite those disadvantages, I’d still prefer to live in a big city.

Meaning: Modifying a previous statement
Examples: In fact, it’s one of the most stressful metro systems in the world.

Meaning: Summarizing
Examples: In short, there are lots of advantages.

Meaning: Use well to introduce a remark or give yourself time to think.
Examples: Who is my favourite family member? Well, I need to think about that one.

Meaning: Use so or therefore to introduce a logical result. So is more informal than therefore.
Examples: Living in a big city has lots of advantages. Therefore, I’d prefer to live there. Living in a big city has lots of advantages. So I’d prefer to live there.

Meaning: Use basically to introduce the most important aspect of something. It is very common - in spoken English (don’t use it in formal writing) and often used as a conversation filler.
Examples: Basically, there are three reasons why I’d like to live in a big city.

Meaning: Use however or yet to make a contrast.
Examples: I agree with that opinion. However, I don’t know if it will be true in the future. I agree with that opinion. Yet I don’t know if it will be true in the future.

Meaning: Though is used to make a contrast. It normally goes at the end of the sentence.
Examples: Living in a big city has lots of advantages. I’d still prefer to live in a small town, though.

Meaning: Use in other words to simplify or summarize what you just said before.
Examples: In big cities, there are more offices and shops. In other words, there is more work.

Meaning: Use If we’re talking ... to introduce a new topic.
Examples: If we’re talking shopping and entertainment, I’d prefer to live in a big city.

Meaning: We use as far as something is concerned when we introduce a new topic. It is a little more formal than If we’re talking ...
Examples: As far as shopping is concerned, it is much better to live in a big city than a small town.

Meaning: Use eventually to say what happens after a long time and/or many problems. The meaning is similar to in the end.
Examples: We drove for two hours trying to find the hotel. Eventually, we gave up and decided to stay at a hostel.

Meaning: Use on top of that or what’s more to introduce an additional point.
Examples: The hotel was awful. On top of that, the weather was cold and wet. The hotel was awful. What’s more, the weather was cold and wet. These connectors are more informal than in addition, furthermore and moreover, so don’t use them in formal writing.

Meaning: Use anyway or anyhow to confirm or support a point or idea just mentioned in a conversation.
Examples: When I was in Italy, I didn’t have time to go for a pizza. Anyway, I don’t really like pizza. You can also use anyway or anyhow to return to something you were talking about before the subject was changed. Anyhow, we finally found a mechanic to fix our car.

Meaning: Use actually to give an unexpected or surprising response.
Use in fact to modify a previous statement, for example if you said something that is slightly inaccurate and you want to be more precise.
Examples: I used to get up at 7am. In fact, it was around 6.30. You can also use

Word: to cut a long story short
Meaning: Use the idiom to cut a long story short (American
Examples: To cut a long story short, I arrived home after midnight.

Meaning: Use on the whole or in general to make a general statement.
Examples: On the whole, I think the food in my country is healthy. In general, I think the food in my country is healthy.

Meaning: Use overall to make a final concluding statement.
Examples: Overall, it was a fantastic holiday. You can also

Meaning: Use for example or for instance to give an example.
Examples: Big cities have more developed public transport. For instance, in my city there are trams, metro systems, buses and trains.

Meaning: You can use alternatively to provide an alternative idea.
Examples: In my town, you can get to the city centre by tram. Alternatively, you can take the bus.
